title: 112_s1985
content:
The "Deficit Reduction Implementation Act" defines a "qualified bill" as a bill with bipartisan support aiming to reduce the deficit by a specified amount over a set period. It outlines the criteria for a bill to be considered bipartisan and focused on deficit reduction. The "Deficit Reduction Implementation Act" allows Senators and Members of the House of Representatives to introduce qualified bills by February 29, 2012. These bills are immediately referred to the appropriate committees for review and scoring by the CBO within 48 hours. The "Deficit Reduction Implementation Act" allows Senators and Members of the House of Representatives to introduce qualified bills by February 29, 2012. These bills are scored based on current guidelines, policies in effect at the time of introduction, and plausible baseline policy assumptions. The scores for each bill will be printed in the Congressional Record and made available online. By March 9, 2012, any Senator can move to proceed to the qualified bill. The "Deficit Reduction Implementation Act" allows Senators and Members of the House of Representatives to introduce qualified bills by February 29, 2012. Any Senator or Member of the House can move to proceed to the consideration of a qualified bill, which will be treated as a joint committee bill under specific sections of the Budget Control Act of 2011. The dates for reporting and voting on passage do not apply to the qualified bill. The "Deficit Reduction Implementation Act" allows Senators and Members of the House of Representatives to introduce qualified bills by February 29, 2012. Any Senator or Member of the House can move to proceed to the consideration of a qualified bill, which will be treated as a joint committee bill under specific sections of the Budget Control Act of 2011. The dates for reporting and voting on passage do not apply to the qualified bill. Additionally, the House or Senate cannot proceed to a qualified bill unless the required scores have been available for at least 72 hours. The provisions of the Budget Control Act of 2011 apply to qualified bills passed by the other House. If the President vetoes a qualified bill, debate on a veto message in the Senate or the House shall be one hour, equally divided between the majority and minority leader, or their designees. This section shall cease to apply to a qualified bill if the bill does not pass both Houses of Congress by March 30, 2012. SEC. 4. APPLICATION OF OTHER PROVISIONS OF BUDGET CONTROL ACT.

A qualified bill that achieves at least $1,500,000,000,000 in deficit reduction will increase the debt limit and cancel discretionary spending limits. SEC. 5. RULEMAKING. SEC. 5. RULEMAKING. This Act is enacted by Congress to establish rules for the House of Representatives and the Senate, superseding other rules if inconsistent, with recognition of the constitutional right of each House to change rules.
